item.title: About The Indoor Eden Co.
item.dc:creator: The Indoor Eden Team
item.content:encoded:
Our Mission

The Indoor Eden Co. was created to help modern urban dwellers create lush, peaceful sanctuaries through intentional indoor plant care and styling.

We believe everyone deserves to experience the joy of living with plants. Our mission is to provide accurate, practical advice that works in real-world conditions, making plant parenthood accessible and rewarding for everyone.

Our Approach

Unlike many plant websites showing perfect specimens in ideal conditions, we focus on:

  • Real-world conditions: Plants in apartments, offices, and small spaces
  • Practical solutions: Advice that works with your lifestyle, not against it
  • Honest recommendations: Products we truly believe in, not just what's trending
  • Accessible information: Clear explanations without confusing jargon

Brand Values

At The Indoor Eden Co., we believe in:

  • Authenticity: We share both successes and failures because plant care is a journey
  • Inclusivity: Plant care should be accessible to everyone, regardless of space or budget
  • Sustainability: We favor eco-friendly products and practices
  • Community: Growing and learning together makes plant care more rewarding

About Our Recommendations

When we recommend products, we focus on value, quality, and performance - not just price. We personally research all products or rely on extensive community feedback to ensure we're only suggesting items that truly work.

Some links on our site are affiliate links, which means we may earn a commission if you purchase through them. This helps support our work and allows us to continue providing free plant care information. We only recommend products we believe in and would use ourselves.

item.title: Contact Us
item.dc:creator: The Indoor Eden Team
item.content:encoded:
Have a question about plant care? Interested in collaborating with us? Or just want to say hello? We'd love to hear from you!

Our team typically responds within 1-2 business days. For quicker answers to common questions, check out our FAQ page.

Ways to Connect

Email: contact@theindooreden.co

Instagram: @theindooredenko

Pinterest: @theindooreden

[contact-form-7 id="contact-form" title="Contact Form"]

item.title: Affiliate Disclosure
item.dc:creator: The Indoor Eden Team
item.content:encoded:
Our Affiliate Relationships

This page contains affiliate links. This means if you click on a link and purchase a product, we may receive a small commission at no additional cost to you.

The Indoor Eden Co. is a participant in the Amazon Services LLC Associates Program, an affiliate advertising program designed to provide a means for sites to earn advertising fees by advertising and linking to Amazon.com and affiliated sites. We also participate in affiliate programs with other retailers and brands that align with our values and the needs of our readers.

How Affiliate Links Work

When you click on an affiliate link on our website, a small piece of tracking code is attached to your browser. If you then make a purchase on the destination website within a certain timeframe (typically 24 hours to 30 days, depending on the program), we earn a commission on that sale.

These commissions help support the operation of The Indoor Eden Co. and allow us to continue creating free, helpful content about indoor plants and their care.

Our Product Recommendation Philosophy

We take our product recommendations seriously, and our affiliate relationships do not influence which products we choose to feature. We only recommend products we genuinely believe in and that we have:

  • Researched extensively
  • Used personally (when possible)
  • Received positive feedback about from multiple reliable sources
  • Verified meet our quality standards

The commissions we earn never influence our product reviews or recommendations. We prioritize honesty and transparency in all our content.

Product Reviews

When we review products, we assess them based on their performance, quality, and valueâ€”not on commission rates. We aim to provide balanced reviews that highlight both the strengths and limitations of products.

If we ever receive free products for review, we will clearly disclose this in the content. However, receiving free products does not guarantee positive reviews.

How We Use Affiliate Income

The affiliate commissions we earn go toward:

  • Website hosting and maintenance costs
  • Creating new, high-quality content
  • Photography and visual resources
  • Research materials and plant care supplies
  • Compensating our team for their work

Identifying Affiliate Links

While we may not label every individual affiliate link on our site, we include disclosure statements:

  • At the beginning of posts containing affiliate links
  • Near product recommendation sections
  • In our website footer

As a general rule, you can assume that most links to products on our site are affiliate links.

Non-Affiliate Content

Much of our content does not include affiliate links. Our plant care guides, troubleshooting articles, and educational content often contain no monetized links at all. We create this content purely to help our readers succeed with their indoor plants.

Contact Us

If you have any questions about our affiliate relationships or how we use affiliate links, please don't hesitate to contact us at contact@theindooreden.co.

Last Updated: April 11, 2025

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: The Indoor Eden Team
item.content:encoded:
At The Indoor Eden Co., we respect your privacy and are committed to protecting your personal information. This Privacy Policy explains how we collect, use, and safeguard your information when you visit our website.

Information We Collect

We collect information that you provide directly to us, such as when you:

  • Subscribe to our newsletter
  • Contact us through our contact form
  • Comment on our content (if applicable)
  • Make a purchase through our affiliate links

This information may include:

  • Name
  • Email address
  • Message content

We also automatically collect certain information when you visit our website, including:

  • IP address
  • Browser type
  • Device information
  • Pages viewed
  • Time spent on pages
  • Referring website

How We Use Your Information

We use the information we collect to:

  • Provide and maintain our website
  • Respond to your inquiries and comments
  • Send periodic emails (if you've subscribed to our newsletter)
  • Improve our website and user experience
  • Analyze how visitors use our site
  • Monitor the effectiveness of our content

Cookies and Tracking Technologies

We use cookies and similar tracking technologies to track activity on our website and store certain information. Cookies are files with a small amount of data that may include an anonymous unique identifier. You can instruct your browser to refuse all cookies or to indicate when a cookie is being sent. However, if you do not accept cookies, you may not be able to use some portions of our website.

Third-Party Disclosure

We do not sell, trade, or otherwise transfer your personally identifiable information to outside parties except as described below:

  • We may use third-party service providers to help us operate our website, such as email services and analytics.
  • We participate in affiliate marketing programs, which means we may receive a commission if you click on affiliate links and make a purchase.
  • We may release your information when we believe release is appropriate to comply with the law, enforce our site policies, or protect our or others' rights, property, or safety.

Data Security

We implement a variety of security measures to maintain the safety of your personal information when you enter, submit, or access your personal information. However, no method of transmission over the Internet or method of electronic storage is 100% secure, and we cannot guarantee its absolute security.

Your Rights

Depending on your location, you may have certain rights regarding your personal information, including:

  • Access to your personal information
  • Correction of inaccurate information
  • Deletion of your information
  • Objection to processing
  • Data portability

To exercise these rights, please contact us at contact@theindooreden.co.

Children's Privacy

Our website is not intended for children under the age of 13. We do not knowingly collect personal information from children under 13. If you are a parent or guardian and you are aware that your child has provided us with personal information, please contact us so that we can take necessary actions.

Changes to This Privacy Policy

We may update our Privacy Policy from time to time. We will notify you of any changes by posting the new Privacy Policy on this page. You are advised to review this Privacy Policy periodically for any changes.

Contact Us

If you have any questions about this Privacy Policy, please contact us at contact@theindooreden.co.

Last Updated: April 11, 2025

item.title: Frequently Asked Questions
item.dc:creator: The Indoor Eden Team
item.content:encoded:
General Plant Care

How often should I water my houseplants?

There's no one-size-fits-all answer, as watering needs depend on your specific plant, pot size, environmental conditions, and season. Rather than following a strict schedule, we recommend checking the soil moisture and looking for signs that your plant needs water. Most indoor plants prefer to dry out slightly between waterings. For specific guidelines, see our care guides for individual plants.

Why are my plant's leaves turning yellow?

Yellowing leaves can be caused by several factors, including overwatering (the most common cause), underwatering, nutrient deficiencies, light issues, temperature stress, or pest problems. Our troubleshooting guide on yellow leaves can help you diagnose and fix the specific issue.

Do indoor plants need fertilizer?

Yes, most houseplants benefit from occasional fertilizing during their growing season (typically spring and summer). Potted plants have limited access to nutrients once they've used what's available in their soil. However, it's better to under-fertilize than over-fertilize, as too much can damage your plants. Most houseplants do well with a balanced houseplant fertilizer diluted to half the recommended strength, applied monthly during growing season.

How do I know if my plant needs repotting?

Signs that your plant needs repotting include:

  • Roots growing out of the drainage holes
  • Roots circling around the inside of the pot (visible when you remove the plant)
  • Water running straight through the pot without being absorbed
  • Plant growth has slowed significantly (despite proper care)
  • The plant becomes top-heavy and falls over easily

Most houseplants benefit from repotting every 1-2 years, either into a slightly larger pot or simply refreshing the soil in the same pot.

Light Requirements

What does "bright indirect light" actually mean?

Bright indirect light means your plant receives plenty of natural light but isn't exposed to direct sun rays. Good locations include:

  • Near an east-facing window
  • A few feet back from a south or west-facing window
  • Next to a north-facing window (in the Northern Hemisphere)
  • A spot where the sun's rays are diffused through a sheer curtain

If you can see a clear, defined shadow of your hand when you hold it up in that spot, it's likely bright indirect light.

Can houseplants survive in rooms with no windows?

Very few plants can survive long-term without any natural light. However, many low-light tolerant plants like ZZ Plants, Snake Plants, and Pothos can survive in rooms with minimal natural light if supplemented with good quality grow lights. Our guide to grow lights for apartments can help you find the right solution.

Plant Selection

What are the best plants for beginners?

The most forgiving plants for beginners include:

  • Snake Plant (Sansevieria)
  • Pothos (Epipremnum aureum)
  • ZZ Plant (Zamioculcas zamiifolia)
  • Spider Plant (Chlorophytum comosum)
  • Chinese Evergreen (Aglaonema)

These plants tolerate inconsistent watering, adapt to various light conditions, and generally communicate their needs clearly. See our complete guide to beginner-friendly plants for more recommendations.

Which houseplants are safe for pets?

If you have cats or dogs, consider these non-toxic options:

  • Spider Plant (Chlorophytum comosum)
  • Boston Fern (Nephrolepis exaltata)
  • Calathea/Prayer Plants (Calathea spp.)
  • Peperomia varieties (Peperomia spp.)
  • Parlor Palm (Chamaedorea elegans)
  • Christmas Cactus (Schlumbergera)
  • African Violet (Saintpaulia)

Avoid toxic plants like Pothos, Peace Lily, and ZZ Plant if you have pets who might chew on them.

Troubleshooting

How do I get rid of fungus gnats?

To eliminate fungus gnats:

  • Let the soil dry out more between waterings (fungus gnats thrive in consistently moist soil)
  • Use yellow sticky traps to catch adult gnats
  • Apply a layer of sand or decorative stones on top of the soil to prevent adults from laying eggs
  • Consider treating with BTI (Bacillus thuringiensis israelensis), a natural bacteria that kills fungus gnat larvae
  • For severe infestations, repot plants in fresh soil

Why does my plant have brown tips on the leaves?

Brown leaf tips are often caused by:

  • Low humidity (especially for tropical plants)
  • Water quality issues (fluoride, chlorine, or high mineral content)
  • Inconsistent watering
  • Fertilizer burn (too much fertilizer)
  • Exposure to hot, dry air (near heaters or air conditioners)

Try increasing humidity around your plants, using filtered or distilled water, and keeping plants away from heating/cooling vents.

Shopping & Product Questions

What should I look for when buying a new houseplant?

When shopping for plants, check for:

  • Overall plant vigor and health (avoid plants with yellowing leaves or signs of stress)
  • New growth (indicates the plant is actively growing)
  • Clean leaves free of spots, holes, or sticky residue
  • No visible pests on the leaves or soil
  • Roots that aren't severely circling or growing out of drainage holes
  • A pot with drainage holes

What potting soil do you recommend for houseplants?

For most common houseplants, we recommend a high-quality indoor potting mix that's lightweight, well-draining, and enriched with some organic matter. Many plants benefit from adding extra perlite or pumice to improve drainage. Specialized plants like succulents, orchids, or African violets require their own specific soil mixes. Check our recommended products page for specific soil recommendations.

Do I need to buy special tools for plant care?

While you don't need many specialized tools to get started with houseplants, a few basic items make care easier:

  • Watering can with a narrow spout
  • Spray bottle for misting (if you have humidity-loving plants)
  • Small pruning shears or scissors
  • Moisture meter (especially helpful for beginners)

As your collection grows, you might want to add a humidifier, grow lights, or specialized tools for repotting.

Other Questions

How do I find the right plants for my specific space?

We recommend assessing your space for three key factors:

  • Light: Observe how much natural light different areas of your home receive throughout the day
  • Humidity: Consider which rooms naturally have higher humidity (bathrooms, kitchens) vs. drier areas
  • Temperature: Note any spots with drafts, near heating/cooling vents, or temperature fluctuations

Then match plants to these conditions rather than trying to make a plant work in an unsuitable environment. Our Start Here guide walks you through this process step by step.

Still have questions?

If your question isn't answered here, please contact us directly and we'll be happy to help!
